text:
Why does betfair divide paid commission by 2 for the purposes of PC? I am not sure I understand this comment:
`We divide by 2 because otherwise we'd be counting each pound of commission twice`

```Commission generated = (Commission + Implied Commission) ÷ 2
where
Implied Commission = market losses x 3%
We divide by 2 because otherwise we'd be counting each pound of commission twice.```

elements.text: Why does betfair divide paid commission by 2 for the purposes of PC? I am not sure I understand this comment:
We divide by 2 because otherwise we'd be counting each pound of commission twice

Commission generated = (Commission + Implied Commission) ÷ 2
where
Implied Commission = market losses x 3%
We divide by 2 because otherwise we'd be counting each pound of commission twice.

text: Because implied commission is commission that someone else has paid

elements.text: Because implied commission is commission that someone else has paid

text: Imagine implied commission is 0, you have an uber model that never loses in any market. You paid £X in commission for the week. Betfair still divides X by 2 for the PC offset?

elements.text: Imagine implied commission is 0, you have an uber model that never loses in any market. You paid £X in commission for the week. Betfair still divides X by 2 for the PC offset?

text: Yeah it's a fair comment and really it's a spectrum depending on the ratio of commission paid to implied commission. But this is clearly all a bit arbitrary. 3% is probably not an accurate number to use for implied commission, for example

elements.text: Yeah it's a fair comment and really it's a spectrum depending on the ratio of commission paid to implied commission. But this is clearly all a bit arbitrary. 3% is probably not an accurate number to use for implied commission, for example

text: So am I correct in thinking that high sortino ratios are heavily penalised by this?

elements.text: So am I correct in thinking that high sortino ratios are heavily penalised by this?

text:
Premium charge is making the by-market-commission pointless anyway, doesn’t it?
I usually ignore the 2% commission when evaluating strategies because I will get some PC on top of it anyway. Or am I missing something?

elements.text:
Premium charge is making the by-market-commission pointless anyway, doesn’t it?

text: Not something I've thought about before <@U01B8031PM1>. It is worth thinking about what the commission generated rate of your strategy is <@U01A8EKD545> because it determines what rate of PC you pay

elements.text: Not something I've thought about before

because it determines what rate of PC you pay

text: there are multiple reasons to want to pay high comissions. txn charge offset and long term PC charge amount offset build up

elements.text: there are multiple reasons to want to pay high comissions. txn charge offset and long term PC charge amount offset build up

text: Hence the div by 2 is super “expensive” in the long run for high sortino strats. Need to pop up the variance per market

elements.text: Hence the div by 2 is super “expensive” in the long run for high sortino strats. Need to pop up the variance per market

text:
Yeah, a strategy that is volatile in its returns pays less PC than one which wins consistently even if they have the same absolute return. 

That’s because a win generates 1% implied comm, and a loss generates 1.5% comm. So in the case you win £100 and lose £100, you’ve generated £2.5 comm for PC, but only paid a physical £2 (from the winning bet). So breakeven strategies actually make you money from a PC perspective if you are on 2% comm.

elements.text: Yeah, a strategy that is volatile in its returns pays less PC than one which wins consistently even if they have the same absolute return.

That’s because a win generates 1% implied comm, and a loss generates 1.5% comm. So in the case you win £100 and lose £100, you’ve generated £2.5 comm for PC, but only paid a physical £2 (from the winning bet). So breakeven strategies actually make you money from a PC perspective if you are on 2% comm.

text: I was always a degen gambler…this is giving me a mathematical reason to increase the variance.

elements.text: I was always a degen gambler…this is giving me a mathematical reason to increase the variance.

text:
I think it’s not really enough of a thing to make much of a difference unless you’re really pushing the limits. 

Like you said, <@U01A8EKD545>, market comm is pretty much irrelevant once you’re paying PC (as long as you’re above a long term 10% to put you in the 40% PC bracket).

elements.text: I think it’s not really enough of a thing to make much of a difference unless you’re really pushing the limits.
Like you said,
, market comm is pretty much irrelevant once you’re paying PC (as long as you’re above a long term 10% to put you in the 40% PC bracket).
